results.title: Through a looking glass: a film on drama
results.creator_credit: Victorian Film Corporation and Vincent O'Donnell
results.brief_description: A Drama in Education teaching film using Year 7 students who had been involved with classes in improvisation and role play. The performances were not directed for the camera.

results.title: Through a glass darkly
results.creator_credit: Svensk Filmindustri, Allan Ekelund and Ingmar Bergman
results.brief_description: Bergman’s “Through a glass darkly” centres on the lives of four characters. Karen (Harriet Andersson) suffers from schizophrenia and has just returned from hospital. She lives on a remote island in the Baltic with her husband Martin (Max Von Sydow) and brother Minus (Lars Passgard). David (Gunnar Bjornstrand), their father, is a novelist who returns from Switzerland to visit them. Gradually the severity of Karen’s illness becomes apparent to them all. Despite it’s dark subject matter “Through a glass darkly” is mesmerising to watch thanks to the outstanding performances by the four actors as well Sven Nykvist’s beautiful cinematography. Winner of 1961 Academy Award for Best Foreign Film. In Swedish with english subtitles.

results.title: Through a broken pane
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig and Blake James
results.brief_description: From an artist’s sketchbook and a poet’s memories, a recollection of life in a country school, a place now derelict and vacant but alive with past associations. The film employs various forms of animation to give life and activity to the old building, looking in through the broken windows at the old desks, the clock on the wall, and looking out at the countryside and what a child might remember of what happened there.

results.title: Throne of blood
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Akira Kurosawa and Shojiro Motoki
results.brief_description: Taketoki Washizu is a general serving-hand and Tsuzuki, the master of Cobweb Castle. Prompted by his wife, Washizu murders Tsuzuki and takes command of Cobweb Castle. He is killed in battle when the son of a rival warlord, one of his victims, attacks the castle. Kurosawa’s visually atmospheric version of Shakespeare’s “Macbeth” stars Toshiro Mifune.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Akira Kurosawa and Shojiro Motoki

results.title: Thrills, skills and spills
results.brief_description: This program targets young, beginning basketballers and their teacher/coach. The basic skills needed to play the game are demonstrated by experts, featuring Phil Smyth and Craig Fitzsimmons together with young players so the beginning player can see a skill performed by someone of his own age and ability. Overviews the rules of the game with segments to show how they are incorporated into the game. This is also an introduction to the game of mini-ball and is a great starter for an Aussie sports basketball program in schools.

results.title: Thrill of the surf
results.brief_description: One of Australia’s national sports vividly pictured for those who live far from an ocean beach. Shows ocean beaches along the coast of New South Wales where surfing is more popular than any other sport. Its thrills include surf-boarding, surf skiing and life-savers rowing surf boats. The lifesaving clubs which exist all along the coastline have more than 13,000 rescues to their credit to date (1949).

results.title: Three women
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, David H. Fowler and David Sims
results.brief_description: A brief encounter with three artists - Alison Duff and Ria Bancroft are sculptors, and Yvonne Rust a potter. The film reflects on how their deep involvement with nature and spiritual matters inspire their work.

results.title: Three wise men of the world
results.brief_description:
A report on the Republic of South Africa - its peoples, cultures and transitions from yesterday into today. The overall socially and economically complex structure is light-heartedly parodied as something which can only too easily appear vastly different to differing observers.
A public relations representation of South Africa in the late 1960s ignoring the contemporary political and racial tensions of the time.
